node.title: Postprocessor to get coordinates from node id
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
Is there happen to be a postprocessor that can get coordinates form the node id? For example, I can use NodalMaxValueId to get the node id I want, is there a way to output the coords of this node?

Hello
you can use paraview with min/max filters on the node id field to locate that particular node.
Do you only have one node you care about?
you could make a new Positions object and this will output the location of the node that this object selects to JSON
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Positions/index.html
Guillaume

I actually want to find a way to track the position of the crack tip in phase field and calculate the velocity in MOOSE. I know I can do it with python and/or paraview, but Positions object might be working for me

You may want to take look at this paper: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/epdf/10.1002/nme.6879
If you want to pursue this I can get their source code for you.
Back to your original question, I think postprocessing the results externally probably is the right way to go, as it's more complicated than just tracking the coordinates of the nodes with phase-field == 1 even if the crack does not branch, unless you know the crack path a priori.

I and Andre noticed this paper, and he wrote some python code on it.
I understand that if we want to track random unknown crack tips (like branching, etc), it  will be better to do it externally.  Here I am just trying to track crack tips for very simple cases, e.g. single crack. here is my workaround:

using a ParsedAux to calculate a distance field to the initial crack tip, say (0, 0): if(d>d_cr, sqrt(x^2+y^2, -100), so that only x(d>d_cr) has a positive distance.
use NodalMaxValueId to get id of the node has largest distance
write a PP (like called NodalPosition..) similar to NodalVaribleValue, but just output the coordinates of this node.

I think this at least will work for single crack, enough for me to do some simple tests.
But yea, I agree we should move to an external solution finally, if you have their code about that paper that will be so nice!

node.title: Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0
node.bodyText:
Hello, I have a converge error like this:
sub0: Time Step 2, time = 864000, dt = 864000
sub0: 
sub0:   Rebuilding Geometric Search Patchessub0: 
sub0:     Reinitializing Because of Geometric Search Objects.                            [ 21.35 s] [ 3055 MB]
sub0:   Finished Rebuilding Geometric Search Patches                                     [ 21.42 s] [ 3055 MB]
sub0:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 4.042263e+06
sub0:   Computing Jacobian                                                               [ 10.95 s] [ 3178 MB]
sub0:       0 Linear |R| = 4.042263e+06
sub0:       1 Linear |R| = 4.952770e+02
Exceeded maximum iterations in material return mapping iterations.
At element 259184 _qp=3 Coordinates (x,y,z)=(0.00420409,  3.48758,        0) block=8887
In 1000 iterations the residual went from 0.000104186 to 0.000104186 in 'CZ_power_law_creep'.

sub0: 
sub0: A MooseException was raised during Auxiliary variable computation.
sub0: The next solve will fail, the timestep will be reduced, and we will try again.
sub0: 
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0
sub0: Finished Solving                                                                   [ 66.05 s] [ 3188 MB]
sub0:  Solve Did NOT Converge!
sub0: Aborting as solve did not converge 

I changed the form of creep in the Power Law Creep Stress Update as a function.The time step 2 here is the first time step of the tensor mechanics calculation. I used to shorten my steps to 1s but nothing changed. I hope someone could help me solve the problem.Thanks!

Hello
We ll probably need the full input file to look at this.
Did step 1 converge well?
Guillaume

Here is the full input file for Tensor Mechanics:
init_temp = 565.75 # K
init_pressure = 6e6 # Pa
outer_pressure = 15.5e6
rad_fuel = 4.096e-3 # m
[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = geometry/cz_no_butterfly.e
  coord_type = RZ

  patch_update_strategy = iteration
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_r disp_z'
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [temp]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = ${init_temp}
  []

  [burnup_per]
    order = FIRST
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [porosity]
    order = FIRST
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

## gas release auxkernel
  [input_material]
     order = FIRST
     family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [q_v]
    order = FIRST
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [fission_rate]
    order = FIRST
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  # creep_strain
  [creep_strain_xx]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [] 
  [creep_strain_yy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [creep_strain_xy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [creep_strain_zz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [burnup_per_aux]
   type = BurnupPerAux
   block = 'fuel'
   q_vol = q_v_fun
   variable = burnup_per
  []

  [porosity]
    type = ParsedAux
    expression = 0.05
    variable = porosity
    block = 'fuel'
  []
## gas release auxkernel
  [gas_release_aux]
    type = GasReleaseAux
    burnup = burnup_per
    q_max = q_max
    vol_fission = vol_fission
    TD = 95
    rad_fuel = ${rad_fuel}
    variable = input_material
  []
  [q_v_aux]
    type = FunctionAux
    function = q_v_fun
    variable = q_v
  []
  [fission_rate_aux]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = fission_rate
    coupled_variables = 'q_v'
    expression = 'q_v / 3.28451e-11' # 3.28451e-11 is once fission release energy
  []

  # creep strain
  #[creep_strain_xx]
    #type = RankTwoAux
    #variable = creep_strain_xx
    #index_i = 0
    #index_j = 0
    #rank_two_tensor = creep_strain
    #block = 'clad'
  #[]
  #[creep_strain_yy]
    #type = RankTwoAux
    #variable = creep_strain_yy
    #index_i = 1
    #index_j = 1
    #rank_two_tensor = creep_strain
    #block = 'clad'
  #[]
  #[creep_strain_xy]
    #type = RankTwoAux
    #variable = creep_strain_xy
    #index_i = 1
    #index_j = 0
    #rank_two_tensor = creep_strain
    #block = 'clad'
  #[]
  #[creep_strain_zz]
    #type = RankTwoAux
    #variable = creep_strain_zz
    #index_i = 2
    #index_j = 2
    #rank_two_tensor = creep_strain
    #block = 'clad'
  #[]
[]

[Contact]
  #active = gap_contact
  [gap_contact]
    primary = 'clad_inside'
    secondary = 'fuel_outer'
    model = frictionless # 
    penalty = 5e3
    formulation = penalty
    tangential_tolerance = 1e-6
    normal_smoothing_distance = 1e-6
  []
  [element]
    primary = 'element_down'
    secondary = 'element_top'
    model = glued
    penalty = 1e9
    normalize_penalty = true
    tangential_tolerance = 1e-3
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  incremental = true
  [fuel]
    strain = FINITE
    add_variables = true
    eigenstrain_names = 'thermal_expansion_eigenstrain'
    generate_output = ' stress_zz vonmises_stress'
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [clad]
    strain = FINITE
    add_variables = true
    eigenstrain_names = 'thermal_expansion_eigenstrain'
    generate_output = ' stress_zz vonmises_stress'
    block = 'clad'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  inactive = 'UO2_radial_return_stress UO2_power_law_creep UO2_solid_swelling UO2_gas_swelling'
  [UO2_density]
    type = UO2Density
    temperature = temp
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [CZ_density]
    type = CZDensity
    temperature = temp
    block = 'clad'
  []
  [UO2_elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor
    args = temp
    youngs_modulus = youngs_modulus
    poissons_ratio = poissons_ratio
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [UO2_elasticity_material]
    type = UO2ElasticityMaterial
    temperature = temp
    density_per = 95
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [CZ_elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor
    args = temp
    youngs_modulus = youngs_modulus
    poissons_ratio = poissons_ratio
    block = 'clad'
  []
  [CZ_elasticity_material]
    type = CZElasticityMaterial
    temperature = temp
    block = 'clad'
  []
  
  [UO2_thermal_expansion]
    type = ComputeUO2InstantaneousThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    stress_free_temperature = 293.
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = thermal_expansion_eigenstrain
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [UO2_radial_return_stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'UO2_power_law_creep'
    tangent_operator = elastic
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [UO2_power_law_creep]
    type = UO2CreepStressUpdate
    temperature = temp
    fission_rate = fission_rate
    q_v_fun = q_v_fun
    density_percent = 95
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [UO2_solid_swelling]
    type = ComputeInstantaneousSolidSwellingEigenstrain
    burnup = burnup_per
    eigenstrain_name = solid_swelling_eigenstrain
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [UO2_gas_swelling]
    type = ComputeInstantaneousGasSwellingEigenstrain
    burnup = burnup_per
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = gas_swelling_eigenstrain
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  
  [CZ_thermal_expansion]
    type = ComputeCZThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    stress_free_temperature = 293.
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = thermal_expansion_eigenstrain
    block = 'clad'
  []
  [CZ_radial_return_stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'CZ_power_law_creep'
    tangent_operator = elastic
    block = 'clad'
    internal_solve_full_iteration_history = true
  []
  [CZ_power_law_creep]
    #type = CZPowerLawCreepStressUpdate
    type = Zr4CreepStressUpdate
    temperature = temp
    max_inelastic_increment = 0.01
    neu_flux_function = neu_flux_fun
    block = 'clad'
    absolute_tolerance = 1e-5
    relative_tolerance = 1e-5
  []
  [small_stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    block = 'fuel'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  active = 'inside coolant_pressure pellet_bottom_disp_z'

  [coolant_pressure]
    type = Pressure
    function = ${outer_pressure}
    boundary = outer
    variable = disp_r
  []
  [inside]
    type = Pressure
    factor = ${init_pressure}
    boundary = 'clad_inside fuel_outer'
    variable = disp_r
  []

  [CavityPressure]
    [cavity_pressure]
      boundary = 'fuel_outer clad_inside plenum_top pin_top pin_bottom'
      initial_temperature = ${init_temp}
      temperature = ave_temp_clad_inside_top# use clad top temperature as average temperature
      material_input = inputmaterial 
      volume = volume_tol
      initial_pressure = ${init_pressure} 
      R = 8.314472
      output = ppress
    []
  []

  [pellet_bottom_disp_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'pin_bottom'
    value = 0.0
    preset = true
  []
  [pellet_bottom_disp_r]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_r
    boundary = 'pin_bottom'
    value = 0.0
    preset = true
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [q_v_fun]
    type = PiecewiseMulticonstant
    data_file = ./power/A-A17.txt
    direction = 'left left'
  []
  [neu_flux_fun]
    type = PiecewiseConstant
    data_file = ./neu_flux/A-A17.txt
    format = rows
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
## gas release postprocessors
  [q_max] ## get the mox volume power
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = q_v
    value_type = max
  []
  [vol_fission] ## get the volume fission unit[fission/s]
    type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = fission_rate
    block = 'fuel'
  []
  [inputmaterial]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = input_material
    block = fuel
    execute_on = 'timestep_end'
  []
  [ave_temp_clad_inside_top]
    type = SideAverageValue
  #  boundary = 'plenum_top'
    boundary = 'clad_inside'
    execute_on = 'initial linear'
    variable = temp
  []
  [volume_tol]
    type = InternalVolume
  #  boundary = 'clad_inside fuel_outer fuel_top plenum_top'
    boundary = 'clad_inside fuel_outer'
    execute_on = 'initial linear'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
   type = SMP
   full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  start_time = 0.
  end_time = 31536000
  dt = 864000
  #[./TimeStepper]
  #  type = TimeSequenceStepper
  #  time_sequence = '0 0.001 3600 86400 864000 1728000 2592000 3456000 4320000 5184000 6048000 6912000 7776000
  #  8640000 9504000 10368000 11232000 12096000 12960000 13824000 14688000 15552000 16416000 17280000 18144000
  #  19008000 19872000 20736000 21600000 22464000 23328000 24192000 25056000 25920000 26784000 27648000 28512000
  #  29376000 30240000 31104000 31536000'
  #[../]
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  l_tol = 1e-5
  l_max_its = 30
  nl_max_its = 30

  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_fator_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu superlu_dist'
  #petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -pc_type -pc_hypre_type -pc_hypre_boomerang_max_iter'
  #petsc_options_value = '201 hypre boomeramg 4'
  line_search = 'none'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  perf_graph = true
[]

[Debug]
 show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

The erro occurs in CZ_power_law_creep which is the returned value of function computeResidualInternal( const GenericReal<is_ad> & effective_trial_stress, const ScalarType & scalar) is a little too big. But I dont know how to fix it.
And the first step is thermal conduction calculation which runs quite well.

can you please upload the mesh and the input file to a git repo?
I cant run this input, I would need this file cz_no_butterfly.e

Here is the thing.
scalar in computeResidualInternal( const GenericReal<is_ad> & effective_trial_stress, const ScalarType & scalar) is always 0 which means the returned value  creep_rate * _dt - scalar is too big to converge. I dont know how scalar is calculated in this process. But the other creep model I used is well converged and scalar in which isn't always 0.
@recuero thoughts?
@jin0123456 are you using your own creep model?
You say you use a function: Can you provide details of your modification?

@recuero @GiudGiud  I'm sorry I can't provide this creep model due to confidentiality agreements.
But I have solved the problem by shortening the time step so I think maybe my creep rate is too big to converge.

node.title: Paraview Error
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am facing a problem with Paraview! I am trying to open moose simulation which is running correctly but I keep having this error message each time :

Thanks

Hello
THis does not look right indeed.
If you run the mesh only with --mesh-only in the command line, and try to open the mesh_name_in.e file, does it work?
Guillaume

node.title: solutions unconverged for porous structures
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE users:
I want to simulate the uniaxial comp with porous lattice structures using moose. The material model is elastic-plastic model with a small hardening for better convergence. but during simulation, the time-stepping is always reducing the minimal, then stopped for both NEWTON and PJFNK. The input files are attached, could you please help me look at this and give me any suggestions?
Thanks!
input_files_zc.zip
ZC

Hello
Please see our page for troubleshooting failing solves:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/failed_solves.html
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
thanks, for a simple structure generated by moose mesh generator, this input script is good.

Interesting.
Do you mind hosting these files, especially the mesh, on a githup repo? Zip isn't a great format for us

Hi,
Please see this: https://github.com/chenyuanming223/test_moose.git
Don't use compute_scaling_once=false it's a bad option. Use preset=false on BCs for plasticity models. Use Newton not PJFNK since the Jacobian is exact.
Linear tet is not a good choice for plasticity either.
You also need to fiddle with the solver. The default solver is not going to work the best.

You also need to fiddle with the solver. The default solver is not going to work the best.

Hi Gary,
You're right, the nolinear convergence residual is too tight I think, compared with Ansys mechanical (the default relative residual for Force is 0.5%). In moose, we have nl_abs_tol and nl_rel_tol, the solver in this simulation checks according to nl_abs_tol?

You also need to fiddle with the solver. The default solver is not going to work the best.

with the hex8, still the error:
We caught a libMesh error in ThreadedElementLoopBase:ERROR: negative Jacobian -2.09741e-06 at point (x,y,z)=( 4.73366,  4.93641, 0.548187) in element 54113
[7] ../src/fe/fe_map.C, line 1173, compiled Apr 20 2023 at 15:32:26
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0
then timestepdroped

the solver in this simulation checks according to nl_abs_tol?

It checks based on both, and the nl_abs_tol default is 1e-50, so it s usually the nl_rel_tol that gets triggered
Is the HEX8 mesh working on the first time step?
Guillaume
If you can upload your hex mesh to that repo, I can quickly make the changes for you. I really should add a troubleshoot page for tensor mechanics...

node.title: Hyperelasticity - can we do it in MOOSE?
node.bodyText:
Hey folks,
My specific question is I'm wondering whether TensorMechanics can model Yeoh hyperelasticity, where the energy density is
$$\sum_{n=1}^{3} A_n (I_1 - 3)^n $$
with $A_n$ specified by the user, and $I_1$ is the first invariant of the Cauchy-Green deformation tensor.
More generally, and probably less usefully, can we model nonlinear elasticity?  Eg, i could differentiate the above with respect to strain to get stress = nonlinear function of strain, and then insert the correct coefficients (=material moduli) into a nonlinear elasticity Material class, if TensorMechanics has one.

ya we have

ComputeLagrangianStressPK1
ComputeLagrangianStressPK2
ComputeLagrangianStressCauchy

Depending on your stress measure.

node.title: Error in using "TerminateControl" module
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts,
I am trying to put control logic for terminating my simulation when postprocessor value reach certain value. However, I am getting following error.
*** ERROR ***
The parameter "_thm_problem" is being retrieved before being set.

Postprocessor
[Postprocessors]
  [average_surface_conc]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = c
    boundary = 'right'
  []
[]

[ControlLogic]
  [threshold]
    type = UnitTripControl
    condition = 'average_surface_conc < conc_ref'
    symbol_names = 'average_surface_conc'
    symbol_values = 'average_surface_conc'
  []

  [terminate]
    type = TerminateControl
    input = threshold:state
    termination_message = 'Surface concentration reached'
  []
[]

Any suggestions?
Best,
Avtar

This control cannot be used outside of the thermal hydraulics module.
i made a change request this week to make this clear, it s very unfortunate timing that you tried to use it today, it will be clear in the documentation that that s not possible very soon

Thanks @GiudGiud
Is there any other way to stop the simulation as soon as following postprocessor reaches certain value?
[Postprocessors]
  [average_surface_conc]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = c
    boundary = 'right'
  []
[]

Use the Terminator It s designed for that purpose
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/Terminator.html
Thanks @GiudGiud

node.title: Quick question: is there a time derivative with coefficient based on material property?
node.bodyText:
Does anybody know of a time derivative kernel that allows a coefficient to be based on a spatially varying material property?
Thanks,
Nabiel

Hello
No there is not.
Would be fairly easy to make though, maybe base it on
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/ADCoefCoupledTimeDerivative.html
If it s for heat conduction you can also use this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative.html
Guillaume

Thanks Guillaume. I'm a novice at this and I have some questions that I hope can be answered simply:

I can imagine that to create the coupled coefficient I can borrow some of the scripts from something like MatDiffusion. But the part that confuses me is that once I have made the .c and corresponding .h file, how would I incorporate it such that it is part of my combined-opt binary?
I suppose this may be related to the first question: where would be best directories to put my custom kernels?

Ideally you create your own application, then you can add it to the src/ and include/ folders in your app.
You could also just add it directly to moose or to a moose module you are using.

definitely your own application
The make output was having a problem with the DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface>

DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>(parameters),
i dont think you need that. Just use a normal constructor for a kernel
If you do want to use that,
then in your header, do you have:
class MatTimeDerivative : public DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>

what is the error exactly?
What would that look like? I am not familiar with this.

What would a normal constructor look like?
To answer your question, the header does not have that line in it. But here is what the error looks like:
/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/MatTimeDerivative.C:29:7: error: type 'DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>' is not a direct or virtual base of 'MatTimeDerivative'
    : DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>(parameters),
      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
take a look at your header, and make sure the parent classes are the same as in the constructor

Sorry Guillaume, but could you write it out for me based on the header file I sent you originally?
I have added the following to my header file to do as you suggested, but now it has returned several more errors:
class MatTimeDerivative : public TimeDerivative, DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>

Here are the errors:
(moose) Nabiels-MacBook-Pro:platypus nabzforcemac$ make -j 8
Rebuilding symlinks in /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/build/header_symlinks
Compiling C++ with suffix (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/modules/module_loader/src/ModulesApp.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/MatTimeDerivative.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/base/PlatypusApp.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/main.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/test/src/base/PlatypusTestApp.C...
Creating resource file
Linking Library /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/modules/module_loader/lib/libmodule_loader_with-opt.la...
Linking Library /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/test/lib/libplatypus_test-opt.la...
/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/MatTimeDerivative.C:29:7: error: type 'DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>' is not a direct or virtual base of 'MatTimeDerivative'
    : DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>(parameters),
      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
make: *** [/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:148: /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/MatTimeDerivative.aarch64-apple-darwin20.0.0.opt.lo] Error 1
(moose) Nabiels-MacBook-Pro:platypus nabzforcemac$ make -j 8
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/MatTimeDerivative.C...
/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/platypus/src/MatTimeDerivative.C:30:10: error: non-static member 'isParamValid' found in multiple base-class subobjects of type 'MooseObject':
    class MatTimeDerivative -> class TimeDerivative -> class TimeKernel -> class Kernel -> class KernelBase -> class ResidualObject -> class MooseObject
    class MatTimeDerivative -> DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<class Kernel> > -> class JvarMapKernelInterface<class Kernel> -> JvarMapInterfaceBase<class Kernel> -> class Kernel -> class KernelBase -> class ResidualObject -> class MooseObject
      _G(isParamValid("G_name") ? getMaterialProperty<Real>("G_name")
         ^
/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseObject.h:129:15: note: member found by ambiguous name lookup

try this
class MatTimeDerivative : public TimeDerivative, public DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel>>
I found the HeatCapacityConductionTimeDerivative kernel that does exactly what I want. Thank you for your help. I am closing this discussion now.
ok good!

node.title: Unphysical oscillations in tangential forces for contact problem
node.bodyText:
I am trying to understand the contact module of MOOSE. As a starting problem, I have a very simple setup: a cube block (box) pressed and slided over another one-element rigid block (plane) with friction. I make the plane as rigid by fixing all its nodes.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  patch_update_strategy = 'iteration'
  volumetric_locking_correction = true
[]

[Mesh]
  [rectangle_body]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin= 20
    xmax = 50
    ymin = 6
    ymax = 36
    zmin = -15
    zmax = 15
    nx = 2
    ny = 2
    nz = 2
    elem_type = HEX
    boundary_name_prefix = 'box'
  []

  [plane_rigid]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin= 0
    xmax = 100
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 5
    zmin = -50
    zmax = 50
    nx = 1
    ny = 1
    nz = 1
    elem_type = HEX
    boundary_name_prefix = 'plane'
    boundary_id_offset = 6
    subdomain_ids = 1
  []

  [cmbn]
    type = CombinerGenerator
    inputs = 'rectangle_body plane_rigid'
  []

  [cmbn_new]
    type = RenameBlockGenerator
    input = cmbn
    old_block = '0 1'
    new_block = 'box plane'
  []
[]

[Variables]
    [disp_x]
    []
    [disp_y]
    []
    [disp_z]
    []
[]

[Functions]
  [ydisp]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 't0   t_end  disp'
    vals = '10.0  20.0    -4'
    value = 'if (t<t0, 0.0, if (t<t_end, disp*(t-t0)/(t_end-t0), disp))'
  []
  [xdisp]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 't0   t_end  disp'
    vals = '20.0  30.0    2'
    value = 'if (t<t0, 0.0, disp*(t-t0)/(t_end-t0))'
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./norm_force_x]
  [../]
  [./norm_force_y]
  [../]  
  [./norm_force_z]
  [../]  
  [./tang_force_x]
  [../]
  [./tang_force_y]
  [../]
  [./tang_force_z]
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./normal_force_x]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = norm_force_x
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = normal_force_x
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./normal_force_y]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = norm_force_y
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = normal_force_y
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./normal_force_z]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = norm_force_z
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = normal_force_z
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./tangential_force_x]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = tang_force_x
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = tangential_force_x
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./tangential_force_y]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = tang_force_y
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = tangential_force_y
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
  [./tangential_force_z]
    type = PenetrationAux
    variable = tang_force_z
    execute_on = timestep_end
    quantity = tangential_force_z
    boundary = box_bottom
    paired_boundary = plane_top
  [../]
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    add_variables = true
    strain = FINITE
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [xfixed]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'plane_top plane_bottom'
    value = 0
  []
  [yfixed]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'plane_top plane_bottom'
    value = 0
  []
  [zfixed]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'plane_top plane_bottom box_top'
    value = 0
  []
  [ydisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = box_top
    function = ydisp
    preset = 0
  []
  [xdisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = box_top
    function = xdisp
    preset = 0
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [strain_all]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    block = 'box plane'
  []

  [Top]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 5
    poissons_ratio = 0.49
    block = 'box'
  []
  [Bottom]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1e6
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    block = 'plane'
  []

[]

[Contact]
  [contact_interface]
    primary = plane_top
    secondary = box_bottom
    formulation = penalty
    model = coulomb
    friction_coefficient = 0.1
    normalize_penalty = true
    penalty = 1e+2
    normal_smoothing_distance = 0.1
  []
[]

[Dampers]
  [contact_slip]
    type = ContactSlipDamper
    secondary = box_bottom
    primary = plane_top
    min_damping_factor = 1e-5
  []
[]
[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu        mumps'
  line_search = contact
  automatic_scaling = true
  contact_line_search_ltol = 1e-3
  nl_max_its = 100
  l_max_its = 40
  start_time = 0.0
  dt = 0.5
  end_time = 30.0

  verbose = true
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-4
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-4
[] # Executioner

[Outputs]
  color = false
  [out]
    type = Exodus
  []
[] # Outputs



When I look at the output, I see that the tangential forces oscillate unphysically. In the figure below, the average tangential force for the contact surface of the box is shown over time. From time 12.5-20s, the contact is established by pressing the box. After 20s, the box is moved in x-direction. The oscillations in x-component of tangential force is clearly unphysical.

However, when I further looked in the code of MechanicalContactConstraint.C in the function computeContactForce, the frictional capacity for the penalty formulation has some different formulation than the literature.
// Frictional capacity
// const Real capacity( _friction_coefficient * (pen_force * pinfo->_normal < 0 ?
// -pen_force * pinfo->_normal : 0) );
const Real capacity(_friction_coefficient *
             (res_vec * pinfo->_normal > 0 ? res_vec * pinfo->_normal : 0));

It seems that the current frictional capacity for penalty method is actually the one for kinematic formulation. Although the formulation from literature is also written there, but it is commented. Is there a reasoning why the formulation for kinematic method is used in penalty method?
Also, when I uncomment the actual penalty formulation for friction capacity, the unphysical oscillations in the results disappear. Is this a bug here?
@bwspenc @recuero for node-face contact

It's hard to know exactly what's happening in the lines of code for your problem. Just a few thoughts:

You say results are unphysical. Even thought that may be true, what's the expected output for that simulation? It helps to know what to expect for a simple test problem.


the frictional capacity for the penalty formulation has some different formulation than the literature:



Is the frictional capacity the issue there? I.e. do you get a tangential frictional vector norm larger than the friction coefficient times the normal force?



when I uncomment the actual penalty formulation for friction capacity, the unphysical oscillations in the results disappear. Is this a bug here?



Do you mean you then get the expected results? You can get non-oscillating results with the wrong physics. Also, I'd try increasing the penalty value to try to obtain closer-to-theory results. Maybe @bwspenc can provide some details on the algorithm.

The expected output for this simulation would be: a symmetrical deformation of the box and symmetric tangential force distribution at the contact surface when the box is pressed; when it is horizontally moved, at least the direction of the tangential force at the contact surface should be consistent according to the direction of the motion of the box.

Currently, as visible in the time plot shown above, the direction of the tangential force in x-direction is changing its direction constantly, even when the block is just pressed. Here, I have again plotted (Fig. 1) the x-component of the tangential force at the center node of the contact surface. In Fig. 2, there is no symmetric x-component tangential force distribution at the contact surface.
Figure 1

Figure 2


Then magnitude of the tangential force vector is not larger than the friction coefficient times the normal force.  However, the direction is changing every time step.
When I use the following formulation for computing frictional capacity

const Real capacity( _friction_coefficient * (pen_force * pinfo->_normal < 0 ?
-pen_force * pinfo->_normal : 0) );

I get the expected result. The box first deforms with tangential forces developing symmetrically when the box is pressed (Fig. 3) and then maintains consistent direction when it is moved horizontally (as shown in figure 4 below after 20s).
Figure 3

Figure 4

Regarding increasing the penalty factor, the original frictional capacity formulation still gives these oscillations, but the time step decreases a lot to achieve convergence. With the new (modified) formulation as in point 3 here, after increasing the penalty factor beyond certain value, the Jacobian becomes negative, probably due to very large deformation causing negative volume elements. It is understandable here that for large penalty factor, the frictional capacity would increase accordingly. And for a soft material as used here, it would cause numerical problems.

I was thinking more along the lines of an analytical solution, but I do agree that, qualitatively, the results with the commented code look more physical. It seems to me that for a penalty method you don't need to use the cached residuals (contact forces) to compute a tangential traction, but I am not fully aware of the details of the algorithms used in node-face.

Regarding increasing the penalty factor, the original frictional capacity formulation still gives these oscillations, but the time step decreases a lot to achieve convergence. With the new (modified) formulation as in point 3 here, after increasing the penalty factor beyond certain value, the Jacobian becomes negative, probably due to very large deformation causing negative volume elements. It is understandable here that for large penalty factor, the frictional capacity would increase accordingly. And for a soft material as used here, it would cause numerical problems.

That makes sense to me. I mentioned increasing the penalty factor because, if selected too small, it can produce very unphysical results.
We'll look into this behavior @npurwar93 (#24632). Thanks for bringing it up.

node.title: Help with issues with rebuilding moose
node.bodyText:

Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/contrib/pcre/src/pcrecpp.cc...

Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/contrib/pcre/src/pcre_stringpiece.cc...

make: *** [/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/contrib/pcre/src/pcrecpp..opt.lo] Error 127

I can't tell if you have activate the necessary Conda environment or not. But this usually occurs when one forgets to:
mamba activate moose
before running make.
This is a little weird though:
/bin/sh: line 0: [: -ne: unary operator expected

Not sure where that's coming from.

Thanks Jason that helped solve the issue, but now I am running into these errors:
/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/src/outputs/PetscOutput.C:151:76: error: use of undeclared identifier 'LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR'
PetscErrorCode ierr = SNESMonitorSet(snes, petscNonlinearOutput, this, LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR);
^
/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/src/outputs/PetscOutput.C:158:71: error: use of undeclared identifier 'LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR'
PetscErrorCode ierr = KSPMonitorSet(ksp, petscLinearOutput, this, LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR);
^
2 errors generated.
make: *** [/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:149: /Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/outputs_Unity.arm64-apple-darwin20.0.0.opt.lo] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....

It looks like there was an update involved (you updated the moose repo, or you updated Conda). When one occurs, so must the other. I am not sure which was done, so we will do them both:
mamba activate moose
cd ~/projects/moose
git pull
mamba update --all
Then, it is necessary to clean up any stale/old build files lying around in the moose repo:
git clean -xfd
Note: this will delete any untracked files. So if you are making changes to moose, be sure to save those changes before running git clean.
Once this is all complete, you should be able to run make again.

Hmm, odd! Can you perform the following:
cd ~/projects/moose
scripts/versioner.py libmesh --yaml | grep install
mamba list | grep moose

Done. This is what the output is:
ImportError: dlopen(/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/bindings.cpython-310-darwin.so, 0x0002): Library not loaded: @rpath/libarchive.13.dylib
Referenced from: <96FF200C-F283-35DD-A021-9DED6415FDD2> /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/libmamba.2.0.0.dylib
Reason: tried: '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/../../../libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/../../../libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin/../lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin/../lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file, not in dyld cache)

There might be something wrong with your PATHs  being created in your startup profile. To be sure, can you open a new terminal, and run the above commands again. But this time, include everything. Including the command I am asking you to run. Example:
Last login: Wed Jun  7 11:32:47 on ttys013
❯ cd ~/projects/moose
scripts/versioner.py libmesh --yaml | grep install
❯ mamba list | grep moose
  install: moose-libmesh=2023.04.19=build_1
❯

Here it is:
Last login: Wed Jun  7 13:45:39 on ttys006
-bash: export: `=': not a valid identifier
The default interactive shell is now zsh.
To update your account to use zsh, please run chsh -s /bin/zsh.
For more details, please visit https://support.apple.com/kb/HT208050.
(base) Nabiels-MacBook-Pro:~ nabzforcemac$ cd ~/projects/moose
(base) Nabiels-MacBook-Pro:moose nabzforcemac$ scripts/versioner.py libmesh --yaml | grep install
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Users/nabzforcemac/projects/moose/scripts/versioner.py", line 25, in 
import yaml
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'yaml'
(base) Nabiels-MacBook-Pro:moose nabzforcemac$ mamba list | grep moose
-bash: __add_sys_prefix_to_path: command not found
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin/mamba", line 7, in 
from mamba.mamba import main
File "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mamba/mamba.py", line 49, in 
import libmambapy as api
File "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/init.py", line 7, in 
raise e
File "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/init.py", line 4, in 
from libmambapy.bindings import *  # noqa: F401,F403
ImportError: dlopen(/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/bindings.cpython-310-darwin.so, 0x0002): Library not loaded: @rpath/libarchive.13.dylib
Referenced from: <96FF200C-F283-35DD-A021-9DED6415FDD2> /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/libmamba.2.0.0.dylib
Reason: tried: '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/../../../libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/libmambapy/../../../libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin/../lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin/../lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/lib/libarchive.13.dylib' (no such file, not in dyld cache)
(base) Nabiels-MacBook-Pro:moose nabzforcemac$

Well there is something wrong with or how mamba is being initialized. Due to the strange operator error that bash is mentioning, it might be due to something at odds in your ~/.bash_profile.
I am guessing you have the initialization routines at the top of the ~/.bash_profile, and later on, something is messing around with paths variables which are affecting Mamba somehow...
Can you show us your bash profile? Might be able to help:
cat ~/.bash_profile

Ah I see. Okay, here it is:
# >>> conda initialize >>>
# !! Contents within this block are managed by 'conda init' !!
__conda_setup="$('/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin/conda' 'shell.bash' 'hook' 2> /dev/null)"
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    eval "$__conda_setup"
else
    if [ -f "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh" ]; then
        . "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh"
    else
        export PATH="/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH"
    fi
fi
unset __conda_setup

if [ -f "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/mamba.sh" ]; then
    . "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/mamba.sh"
fi
# <<< conda initialize <<<

export = PATH=$PATH:$HOME/projects/moose/python/peacock/

While that may solve the operator error... I think that that PATH= line would not break Mamba...
You might need to reinstall Mamba. If you've only been using Conda for MOOSE based stuff, it should be safe to delete, and re-install...
rm -rf /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3


Apple Silicon Mac:
curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Mambaforge-MacOSX-arm64.sh
sh Mambaforge-MacOSX-arm64.sh -b -p /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3


Intel Mac:
curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Mambaforge-MacOSX-x86_64.sh
sh Mambaforge-MacOSX-x86_64.sh -b -p /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3


Exit your terminal, and re-open it... see if you can run mamba commands without those errors:
mamba list
If the above works without those crazy errors, you'll need to re-create the 'moose' environment:
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
mamba activate moose
and hopefully, you should be able to build once more.

node.title: Make a csv file from a class that derives from “Material”
node.bodyText:
I am writing a class that derives from “Material.”
My program includes such as:
.
_length(declareProperty<Real>("length")),
_temperature(coupledValue("heat_variable"))
.

float some_constant = 100;
_length[_qp] = some_constant * _temperature[_qp];

Now, I would like to generate a csv file includes member variable “_length[_qp].”
Please help.
S. Thomas

hello
Just set the output_properties and outputs parameter in the input for this Material.
Or do you want "output" to always be done?
[Materials]
[ my _mat ]
   ...
   output_properties= 'length'
    outputs = 'csv'
  []
[Outputs]
  [csv]
    type = CSV
  []
[]

Thank you GiudGiudty,
Are you suggesting to use "type = OutputTestMaterial?"
Yes, I would like it done always.
Sincerely,
S. Thomas

no the type is the type of your Material.
Always might be difficult actually, because the csv output block might not exist.
You could set the default of outputs to 'all' ?

For a quick check, I am using the below.
It did not make a csv file but the 'diff_u' is included in the exodus file.
A csv file is supposed to be generated, isn't it?
Please help.
[Materials]
  [./conduct_u]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'diff_u'
    prop_values = 1.0
    block = 0
    output_properties = 'diff_u'
    outputs = 'csv'
  [../]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  [csv]
    type = CSV
  []
[]

I remember that the Elemental variable family is not shown in a csv file. So, 'diff_u' may have the Elemental variable family. I will work on my "_length[_qp]" to see if I can print it in a csv file.
Sincerely,
S. Thomas

oh  somehow I did not connect that this CSV output wasnt going to get set up automatically.
This wont work. Let me find a different solution

This is the object you want to use
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/MaterialVectorPostprocessor.html

Thank you, Guillaume!
Actually I would like to make a CSV file for values along boundary lines. In that case, do you recommend to use "LineValueSampler" or any other methods like giving the boundary numbers (or names) instead of coordinates.  Please help. S. Thomas

If the boundaries are straight lines, then LineValueSampler is the one to go with.
If not, then we do not have a BoundaryValueSampler.
However, if you are OK with the odd workflow you could:

use LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator on the boundary of interest
use the ElementValueSampler and block restrict it to that lower D block
